page.title: 04Adisham Tourists and Ecology
page.content: Adisham contains a few cottages which are let to tourists in summer. The Public House attracts people from out- side the area and there are passing visitors. They like the quiet and lovely footpath walks available through the Downs. The village is not beautiful but there at least four medieval houses and the l3th Century Church. Ancient woodland fringes Water Tower Woods, but a quarter has been destroyed by coniferous high forest. The remainder are ancient modified beech coppice woods, inhabited by foxes, game birds, woodpeckers, nightingales, and tree creepers among others. Some hedges and lines of trees still remain on the lower slopes. Orchids grow in more remote parts, some wild flowers are left, and butterflies, mainly cabbage white. The village pond is now a green and frogs try to live in garden ponds.
